case_name: M/s. K. D. Kamath and Company v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1242 of 1968 filed by special leave from Mysore High Court judgment dated January 21, 1964 in I.T.R.C. No. 13 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1242 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 21, 1964 of the Mysore High Court in I.T.R.C. No. 13 of 1963.

facts.text: Partnership deed dated March 20, 1959 marked Ex. A constitutes the appellant firm with six partners.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, raises the. question whether the, deed dated March 20, 1959 and marked Ex. A is an Instrument of Partnership on the basis of which the ,appellant firm is eligible to be granted registration under S. 26A of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  hereinafter to be referred as the Income-tax Act .

facts.text: Appellant firm consists of six partners constituted under document dated March 20, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a firm companysisting of six, partners and the partnership was companystituted under the document dated March 20, 1959.

facts.text: Business of the partnership carried on from October 1, 1958 as recited in the deed.

anchor.surface_text: The business of the partnership, as recited in the deed. is stated to have been carried on in partnership from October 1, 1958.

facts.text: Partnership registered under Indian Partnership Act, 1932 on or about August 11, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The partnership was registered under the Indian Partnership Act, 1932,  hereinafter to be referred as the Partnership Act  on or about August II,, 1959.

facts.text: Appellant filed application for registration u/s 26A for assessment year 1959-60 corresponding to previous year ending March 31, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1959-60, companyresponding to the previous year ending March 31, 1959, the appellant filed an application to the Income-tax Officer, A Ward, Dharawat under s. 26A for registration of the partnership in the name of M s. K. D. Kamath and Company.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer declined registration on September 28, 1960 holding no genuine partnership by deed of March 20, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer by his order dated September 28, 1960 declined to grant registration on the ground that there was numbergenuine partnership brought into existence by the deed of March 20, 1959 and that the claim of the firm having been companystituted is number genuine.

facts.text: ITO held business is sole concern of K. D. Kamath relying on clauses 8,9,12,16.

anchor.surface_text: The said officer further held that the business should be held to be the sole companycern of K. D. Kamath. For companying to this companyclusion, the Income-tax Officer has mainly relied on clauses 8, 9, 12 and 16 of the partnership deed.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO order on May 5, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the assessee, the Appellate Assistant Commis- sioner on May 5, 1961 companyfirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal allowed appeal in I.T.A. No. 3220 of 1961-62 for AY 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee carried the matter in further appeal I.T.A. No. 3220 of 1961-62  Assessment year 1959-60  before the. Income-, tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay Bench B.

facts.text: Tribunal held deed creates partnership relationship and directed registration u/s 26A.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately, the Appellate Tribunal held that the partnership deed makes it clear that profits and losses are to be shared between the parties and that, subject to the over-riding authority of K. D. Kamath, the other partners companyld act for the firm.

facts.text: Commissioner applied for reference u/s 66(1) on October 4, 1962, numbered 66-RA-978 of 1962-63.

anchor.surface_text: herein, made an application on October 4, 1962 under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act praying for a reference being made by the Appellate Tribunal to the High Court of the question of law mentioned in the application.

facts.text: Mysore High Court answered question against assessee on January 21, 1964 in I.T.R.C. No. 13 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its judgment and order dated January 21, 1964 in I.T.R. C. No. 13 of 1963 answered the question ,referred to it against the assessee and held that the appellant firm companyld number be granted registration under s. 26A for the assessment year 1959-60.

facts.text: High Court held no agency element in partnership deed based on clauses 5-9,12,16.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has generally companysidered the effect of cls. 5 to 9, 12 and 16 of the partnership deed. ... On this reasoning, the High Court has companye to the companyclusion that there is numberrelationship of partners created under the partnership deed

facts.text: Partnership deed executed at Hubli on March 20, 1959 among six named partners.

anchor.surface_text: Articles of agreement made at Hubli, this 20th day of March, 1959, Among  1  Shri krishnarao Dadasaheb Kamat, hereinafter 1040 called the Party hereto of the 1st part,  2  Shri Narayan Ganesh. kamat hereinafter called the party hereto of the 2nd part,

facts.text: Partners: 1. Krishnarao Dadasaheb Kamat (Party 1), 2. Narayan Ganesh Kamat, 3. Shripadrao Damodara Kamat, 4. Dnyanoba Jotiram Mohite, 5. Shankar Govind Joshi, 6. Yashavant Bhawoo Kate.

anchor.surface_text: 1  Shri krishnarao Dadasaheb Kamat ... 2  Shri Narayan Ganesh. kamat ... 3  Shri Shripadrao Damodara Kamat ... 4  Shri Dnyanoba Jotiram Mohite ... Shri Shankar Govind Joshi ... Shri Yashavant Bhawoo Kate

facts.text: Sole proprietary concern of K.D. Kamath converted to partnership by admitting parties 2-6 as working partners, effective from October 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: party No. i.e. Shri K. D. Kamat has been pleased to companyvert his sole proprietary companycern, as a partnership companycern, by admitting the above parties from 2 to 6 as working partners ... business of the partnership is agreed and is being carried on accordingly in partnership as from 1st Day of October, 1958

facts.text: Profit sharing ratios: K.D. Kamath 5 shares, others 2 each, total 15 shares.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Krishnarao Dadasaheb Kamat 5 shars Shri Narayan Ganesh Kamat 2 shares Shri Shri Dadarao Damodara Kamat 2 shares Shri Dayanoba Jotiram Mohite 2 shares Shri Shankar Govind Joshi 2 shares Shri Yashavant Bhawoo Kate 2 shares ------------------- TOTAL 15 shares

facts.text: K.D. Kamath is principal financing and managing partner, others working partners contributing labour.

anchor.surface_text: That it is agreed among the partners that the party No. 1, i.e., Shri K. D. Kamat, shall be the principal and financing partner and the rest of the partners i.e. from 2 to 6 are admitted only as working partners companytributing labour.

facts.text: K.D. Kamath has full control and management, working partners work under his instructions.

anchor.surface_text: Shri K. D. Kamat, who is the principal and financing partner ... shall have full right of companytrol and management of the firms business ... all the working partners from 2 to 6 shall always work according to the instructions and directions given from time to time by Shri K. D. Kamat

facts.text: Working partners cannot raise loan or pledge firm interest without written authority of K.D. Kamath.

anchor.surface_text: numberworking partner or partners is are authorised to raise a loan for and on behalf of the firm or pledge the firms interest directly or indirectly and such an act shall number be binding on the firm, except under the written authority of the principal partner.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds partnership deed creates valid partnership relationship satisfying s.4 Partnership Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that under the partnership deed the relationship which has been brought into existence between the six parties is a relationship of partners who have agreed to share the profits and losses of business carried on by all or any of them acting for all and it satisfies the definition of Partnership under s. 4 of the Partnership Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court answers question in affirmative, firm eligible for registration u/s 26A for AY 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: In, the result, we answer the question of law in the affirmative in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee carried the matter in further appeal I.T.A. No. 3220 of 1961-62  Assessment year 1959-60  before the. Income-, tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay Bench B. The Appellate Tribunal, after a reference to the relevant clauses in the partnership deed, came to the companyclusion that the two essential requirements as laid down by the companyrts for determining whether there is a partnership, namely, an agreement between the parties to hare profits and each of the parties acting as agent of all, are fully satisfied in this case.

arguments.claim: Five circumstances from cls.8,9,16 show no agency: full control with Kamath, others work under directions, cannot accept business/raise loans without consent.

arguments.court_reasoning: Restrictions by contract valid; does not destroy agency principle in s.4.

arguments.claim: Partnership exists per s.4 Partnership Act: agreement to share P/L, business by all/any acting for all (agency implicit).

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that under the partnership deed the relationship which has been brought into existence between the six parties is a relationship of partners who have agreed to share the profits and losses of business carried on by all or any of them acting for all and it satisfies the definition of Partnership under s. 4 of the Partnership Act.

arguments.claim: Conditions for s.26A registration satisfied: valid genuine partnership per instrument.
Control/management by one partner not destructive of partnership (Steel Brothers precedent).
M.P. Davis distinguishable: extreme case with no real partner intent, unlike here.
Restrictions on authority valid per ss.11,20 Partnership Act; inter se, not affecting agency principle.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt under s. 18 of the Partnership Act, a partner is the agent of the firm for the purpose of the business of the firm. But that section itself clearly says that it is subject to the provisions of the Act. It is open to ,the- parties, under s. 11, to enter intoan agreement regarding their mutual rights and duties

arguments.claim: Umarbhai distinguishable: extreme control by father, no real sharing/agency; unlike here.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Iyer placed companysiderable reliance as the High Court has also done, on the earlier decision of the Bombay High Court in Umarbhai Chandbhai v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City 1 . That again, in our opinion, was a case of an extreme nature where, under a partnership deed, between the father and his two sons

arguments.claim: Cl.9 restriction on loans/pledge valid contract per s.14,20; recognizes agency but restricts.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of the Partnership Act itself clearly shows- that the provisions companytained therein are subject to the companytract between the parties. We have already held that the provision regarding the companytrol and management vesting in party No.1 is number itself destructive of the theory of partnership.

arguments.claim: Profit/loss sharing per cl.5 satisfies first limb of s.4; management by Kamath acts for all.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  5  provides that final accounting is to be taken as on March 31 of every year and the net profits and losses are to be shared by the parties thereto in the proportion of the shares specified in the said clause. ... Therefore, one of the essential ingredients to companystitute partnership, namely, that there should be an agreement to share the profits and the losses of the business is more than amply satisfied

holdings.text: under the partnership deed the relationship which has been brought into existence between the six parties is a relationship of partners who have agreed to share the profits and losses of business carried on by all or any of them acting for all and it satisfies the definition of Partnership under s. 4 of the Partnership Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that under the partnership deed the relationship which has been brought into existence between the six parties is a relationship of partners who have agreed to share the profits and losses of business carried on by all or any of them acting for all and it satisfies the definition of Partnership under s. 4 of the Partnership Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.5 specifies profit/loss sharing ratios; control vested in party No.1 who carries on business acting for all per clauses 1,6,8; satisfies both essential conditions under s.4 Partnership Act.

holdings.text: one of the essential ingredients to constitute partnership, namely, that there should be an agreement to share the profits and the losses of the business is more than amply satisfied in this case.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  5  provides that final accounting is to be taken as on March 31 of every year and the net profits and losses are to be shared by the parties thereto in the proportion of the shares specified in the said clause. ... Therefore, one of the essential ingredients to constitute partnership, namely, that there should be an agreement to share the profits and the losses of the business is more than amply satisfied

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.5 explicitly provides for sharing net profits/losses in specified shares among all six parties.

holdings.text: as the partnership business is carried on by party No. 1, acting for all, the second condition of agency is also satisfied.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Managing partner (party No.1) carries on business for all partners per clauses vesting control/management in him; reinforced by cl.16 for mutual benefit.

holdings.text: the provision regarding the control and management vesting in party No.1 is not itself destructive of the theory of partnership.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Control by one partner not destructive per Steel Brothers; business carried by him acting for all satisfies agency in s.4.

holdings.text: Clause 9 in our opinion, itself shows that the theory of agency is recognised. But the parties, by mutual agreement, have placed a restriction on the working partners right to borrow on behalf of the firm or pledge the firms interest without the written authority of the principal partner.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  9  in our opinion, itself shows that the theory of agency is recognised. But the parties, by mutual agreement, have placed a restriction on the working partners right to borrow on behalf of the firm or pledge the firms interest without the written authority of the principal partner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restrictions valid inter se per ss.11,18,20 Partnership Act; do not negate agency principle in s.4 as subject to contract.

holdings.text: it follows that conditions Nos. 1, 2 and 3 specified in the above decision are fully satisfied. Regarding Condition No. 4 also there is no controversy that the partnership is genuine... the relationship of partners inter se has been created under the partnership deed and that such relationship had actually existed in accordance with the terms specified in the said document.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application made per rules (1); instrument exists (2); shares specified in cl.5 (3); valid/genuine per s.4 analysis (4); ITO bound to register absent s.23(4) violation.

holdings.text: we answer the question of law in the affirmative in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In, the result, we answer the question of law in the affirmative in favour of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deed creates valid partnership satisfying s.4 Partnership Act and s.26A conditions; reverses High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that under the partnership deed the relationship which has been brought into existence between the six parties is a relationship of partners who have agreed to share the profits and losses of business carried on by all or any of them acting for all and it satisfies the definition of Partnership under s. 4 of the Partnership Act.
In, the result, we answer the question of law in the affirmative in favour of the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  5  provides that final accounting is to be taken as on March 31 of every year and the net profits and losses are to be shared by the parties thereto in the proportion of the shares specified in the said clause. ... Therefore, one of the essential ingredients to constitute partnership, namely, that there should be an agreement to share the profits and the losses of the business is more than amply satisfied
In, the result, we answer the question of law in the affirmative in favour of the assessee.
